text.headline: The Life of His Eminence Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche: A Timeline
text.text: Welcome. This timeline offers a journey through the extraordinary life, teachings, and accomplishments of one of the greatest masters of the Yungdrung Bön tradition. Scroll to explore key events, from his early years in Tibet to the founding of important institutions and the transmission of precious teachings across the world.

text.headline: Birth
text.text: His Eminence Yongdzin Tenzin Namdak Rinpoche was born in 1926 in Khanyin village, located in the Khyungpo region of Kham, eastern Tibet.

text.headline: Moves to Tengchen Monastery
text.text: Rinpoche went to Tengchen Monastery, where he was under the care of his uncle.

text.headline: Tangka painting apprentice
text.text: Started mural painting in his homeland in Tengchen

text.headline: Mural painting
text.text: Between 1940 and 1942, at the age of around fourteen, Rinpoche journeyed with a maternal uncle to Yungdrung Ling Monastery—one of the great centres of Bön in central Tibet. Initially joining as an assistant in a mural-painting project, he soon came under the guidance of senior lamas.

text.headline: Became an ordained monk (Tenzin Namdak)
text.text: As a youth with a clear calling, Rinpoche sought the finest teachers and training within the Bön tradition. In 1943, at the age of 17, he undertook a two-day trek to Menri Monastery in Tsang, central Tibet – the premier monastery of the Bön tradition to formally become a monk. There, he received monastic vows from Gyaltsab Tsakpé Gelong and Sonam Rinchen, taking the ordination name Tenzin Namdak, meaning “Guardian of the Essence of the Pure Doctrine of Buddha.

text.headline: Moves to Tengchen Monastery
text.text: Nepal and Mount Kailash

text.headline: Returns from pilgramage to Yungdrung Ling monastery
text.text: Studying in Yungdrung Ling monastery

text.headline: Living and studying in the cave with yongdzin tshultrim Gyaltshen
text.text: Between 1944 and 1948, he apprenticed under his root teacher, Gangru Tsültrim Gyaltsen Rinpoche, a retired lopön (head teacher) of Yungdrung Ling. Together, they retreated to a remote cave by Juru Tso Lake in northern Tibet, where Yongdzin Rinpoche undertook intensive training. In this secluded hermitage, he studied a broad range of subjects—from grammar and poetry to cosmology and the stages of the path—as well as the advanced meditation teachings of Sutra, Tantra, and Dzogchen.

text.headline: Returs to Menri monastery
text.text: In late 1948, following his first teacher’s advice, Yongdzin Rinpoche returned to Menri Monastery to complete the rigorous scholastic programme for the Geshe degree (equivalent to a doctorate in philosophy). His principal mentor at Menri was Lopön Sangye Tenzin Rinpoche, one of Bön’s greatest scholars of the era.

text.headline: Received Geshe Degree
text.text: Awarded the highest monastic degree at Menri

text.headline: Appointed Lopön of Menri
text.text: Appointed head teacher of Bön's premier monastery and became responsible for Mentri monastery in Tibet

text.headline: Disciple Becomes 32nd Abbot of Menri
text.text: Had a divinatory appointment ritual for the appointment of the Menri abbot

text.headline: Spiritual Retreat at Dangra Lake
text.text: Retreating in Sezhing monastery on the Dangra lake in northern Tibet

text.headline: Captured and Escapes Tibet
text.text: Captured, imprisoned, escaped to Nepal

text.headline: Arrives in the UK on Rockefeller Grant
text.text: Invited by David Snellgrove to SOAS, London. Supported by the Rockefeller Foundation for research

text.headline: Returns to India
text.text: Rejoined the exile Bön community

text.headline: Founds Tibetan Bönpo Foundation in India
text.text: Registered the Foundation in the indian state of Uttar Pradesh

text.headline: Establishes Dolanji Tibetan Refugee Settlement
text.text: Establishing the Dolanji Tibetan Refugee settlement in India

text.headline: Publishes *The Nine Ways of Bön*
text.text: Co-authored the first major Western academic study on Bön

text.headline: Initiates Menri Monastery in Exile
text.text: Electing the 33rd abbot, Menri Trinzin

text.headline: Facilitates Election of 33rd Abbot of Menri
text.text: Facilitated the election of the 33rd abbot of Menri after the death of the previous abbot while Rinpoche was in London, Geshe Sangye Tenzin became the 33rd abbot, who was then welcomed back from Oslo to India in November 1969. was the name of Lungtok Tenpai Nyima,

text.headline: Visiting Scholar at University of Munich
text.text: Collaborated on Tibetan-English dictionary

text.headline: Rebuilds Menri Monastic Life in Exile
text.text: Full engagement with monastic life in Menri India, printing Bön texts, reconstruction of Menri Monastery in India, engaged in teaching, practising and writing

text.headline: Establishes Dialectic School at Menri
text.text: The same year, bestowing initiation and teaching of the Gyubuchung Cunyi (twelve little tantras) to Choegyal Namkhai Norbu Rinpoche and his students who visited Menri monastery and the Bon settlement for teachings

text.headline: Devotes Time to Teaching and Writing
text.text: Teaching full time in the dialectic school of Dolanji Menri Monastery

text.headline: Confers First Secret Empowerments
text.text: Bestowing his first inner, outer, and secret empowerments of Yungdrung Bon to the lay and ordained devotees of Bön, including the 33rd abbot of Menri monastery

text.headline: Bestows First Geshe Degree at Menri
Returns to Tibet to Bestow Teachings and Transmissions
text.text: Returning to Tibet for the first time since exhile bestowing teaching and transmission to devotees of Bön, visirting several Bön monasteries in Shingatse, Qamdo, Nagqu, Stengchen, Kongpo, Zingchu, Amdo Ngaba, ordaining monks, performing rituals, and transmission, and performing the dialectic school in menri monastery Tibet, presiding over the inauguration ceremony of a new dielctic school in Ri Tsedrug monastery, appointing the abbot of Dingchen monastery, his diciples went under process of oral examination as if they were taking the geshe exam in front of the congretion of monks led by the head teacher Kinzang Lodro in Yungdrung Ling monastery

text.headline: Founds Triten Norbutse Monastery
text.text: Established the only major Bön monastery in Kathmandu, Nepal.

text.headline: Continues Teaching at Menri in India
text.text: Teaching at Menri while supervising the construction of Triten Norbutse in Nepal

text.headline: Begins First Western Teaching Tour
text.text: Taught Dzogchen in the UK, USA, Italy at the invitation of Namkhai Norbu

text.headline: Teaches Dzogchen Across the West
text.text: France, UK, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, USA, Mexico, Holland, Argentina, Thailand

text.headline: Attends Kalachakra with H.H. Dalai Lama invitation
Second Return to Tibet for Teachings
text.text: Meeting with heirs of Shen lineage, Norbu Wangyal, visiting several Bon monasteries in Nagqu, Qamdo, Teng-chen, bestowing local monks initiation, transmission, teaching, and ordinating monks, consecrating and performing and teaching rituals

text.headline: Third Visit to Tibet and Rituals in Lhasa
text.text: Meeting Shen Norbu Wangyal and his sons in Lhasa, meeting with the 33rd abbot in Lhasa and performing rituals together with him for devotees

text.headline: Inaugurates New Temple at Triten Norbutse
text.text: Establishing the dialecting and meditation school at Triten Norbutse

text.headline: Appoints Triten Norbutse Council
text.text: Drafting the structure and function of the Triten Norbutse

text.headline: Leads Bön Mandala Project in Osaka
text.text: Cooperation with the National Museum of Ethnology in Osaka, supervising the painting of 130 mandalas from the relevant text of the Bön religion, which were exhibited and collected in the museum, giving instructions for the writing and publishing of the Bon Mandalas

text.headline: Fourth Return to Tibet for Teaching and Ordinations
text.text: Meeting Shen Norbu Wangyal and a number of monasteries in Teng-chen and Ba chen consecrating, initiating and giving transmissions in these monasteries, inaugurating the dialectic school in Teng-chen monastery, sponsoring and initiating the Tibetan medical school in Teng-chen county

text.headline: Bestowing First Geshe Degree at Triten Norbutse
text.text: Bestowing First Geshe Degree at Triten NorbutseTriten Norbutse Monastery

text.headline: Electing the abbot of Triten Norbutse
text.text: Appointed his disciple Jeru Geshe Tenpa Yungdrung as the abbot of Triten Norbutse Monastery

text.headline: Bestows Series of Secret Empowerments
text.text: Bestows Series of Secret Empowerments to lay and monastic community at Triten Norbutse monastery

text.headline: Founds Shenten Dargye Ling Retreat Centre
text.text: Established French retreat centre; Bön recognised in France

text.headline: Publishes 13-Volume Collected Works
text.text: Publication in India

text.headline: French Government Recognises Shenten Dargye Ling
text.text: By the Ministry of the Interior of the French government

text.headline: Relocates Tibetan Medical School to Triten Norbutse
text.text: Relocating the Tibet Medical School from Dhorpatan to Triten Norbutse

text.headline: Final Return to Tibet and Ordains 150 Monks
text.text: Meeting Shen Norbu Wangyal, Gyalse yungrung Gyalwa, giving teachings and transmissions of the primary practice to the family members of Shen and meeting devotees from various parts of Tibet, ordaining more than 150 monks, identifying and visiting Bon sacred sites

text.headline: Visits Zhu Rizhing and Blesses New Sites
text.text: Visiting Zhu Rizhing Yungdrung Kundragling, inaugurating the meditation school there and visiting the newly purchased site for the future school of Sheing Phunthogling Bon Society in India, blessing and consecrating the site where the Tise Himalayan International School by Triten Norbutse would be located

text.headline: Oversees Stupa Construction at Shenten
text.text: Presiding over the stupa construction of the Yungdrung Loeg stupa

text.headline: Sends Relics Back to Menri in Tibet
text.text: Sending back two important images to the Menri monastery in Tibet

text.headline: Completes Dzogchen Transmission to Western Lay Practitioners
text.text: Bestowing transmission and teachings of Zhang Zhung Nyengund Kagyud Korzhi completely to lay practitioners of the summer retreat of Shenten

text.headline: Guides 34th Abbot Election at Menri
text.text: Provides instructions for the 34th election of the Menri abbot

text.headline: Blesses 34th Abbot and Supports School Opening
text.text: Supporting the opening of the Tise Himalayan school, presiding over the Dutrisu ceremony in the autumn retreat of Shenten

text.headline: Begins Construction of New Temple at Triten Norbutse
Celebrates 95th Birthday with Devotees
text.text: Joined by housands of devotees from various countries of the East and West

text.headline: Publishes Complete 22-Volume Collected Works
text.text: Publishing the full 22. volume of his works and the second edition of the 13 volumes of the previous works

text.headline: Moves into New Residence at Completed Temple
Inaugurates New Temple During Centennial
text.text: During the 100th year ceremony

text.headline: 100th Birthday Celebration
text.text: Centennial celebrated with 6000 devotees

text.headline: Enters Thukdam and Parinirvana
text.text: Passed away peacefully on June 12 during Saga Dawa
